body.name: Triplanetary: Science fiction novel and space opera by American writer - E.E. Smith's Interstellar Saga: Delving into the World of Triplanetary

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Reading Old Friends Again
reviews.reviewText: I haven't read this book in at least 2 decades. It was just as stirring & suspenseful as when I 1st read it. Though I have read this book many times. I lost my library of books just over a decade ago. Among them were many classic Sci Fi writers. Asminov, Norton. Clark, Niven & many others. I must say though I have read some contemporary Sci Fi but I like the science fiction I grew up on from the early 60s on. I am now on a quest to find those grand old books buy & read them again. They will be like old friends long lost coming to know them once again. They are classic Science Fiction for a reason. The have stood test of time & found not wanting. Read them for those Sci Fi writers stand on the shoulders of those giants. Find out what made today's writers want be the next generation of writers by reading those books.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2016
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great SCI FI book but lousy with typos
reviews.reviewText: This is the first book in the Lensman series and sets the tone and universe for all six books ( plus 3 by David Kyle). I first read it years ago and it still holds interest the same way. However, I will say that the Kindle version of this book and all the others available from Amazon (Grey Lensman is not available on Kindle as yet) have the worst typo's and print errors including missed sentences and paragraphs I have ever seen in any books on Kindle. They should get their act together and get some proofreaders. Knowing the books as well as I do, it is easy to spot missing lines, but the typos are major.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I love this series
reviews.reviewText: I read some of this series in paperback book form. I didn't realize the books were out of print. It was lovely to find them in ebook form!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Small type, and very narrow margins. But the price is right.
reviews.reviewText: This is the "Lensman" version of Doc Smith's Triplanetary. The book has long-since fallen into the Public Domain, and affordable copies of it (in either the original or "Lensman" version) are not easy to find, and truly good affordable copies simply don't exist.The small type and narrow margins manage to squeeze the text into a mere 104 pages, but they also make it very fatiguing to read, hence it only rates three stars.But it's an affordable copy of the "Lensman" version, and that was what I was after.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I read the Lensmen series many years ago and I thoroughly enjoyed them then. Reading these books again now I enjoyed them even more. They are a SciFi series of a different kind. They are very real and actually could have really happened in the past or might be part of our future. I can only recommend this series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lensman Series book one
reviews.reviewText: It is a fast paced story, with enough action for any adventurer.. Although women are not equals, they or some of them are at least considered intellectual. Some of the storylines are a little tripe. It is more like "Flash Gordon" than "Star Trek", but all in all a good read. I am currently on the fifth book of the series. So if you don't mind the comic book style of writing with super heroic shenanigans then you will enjoy this series as well.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Don't expect a dumbed down vocabulary
reviews.reviewText: Classic science fiction, and one of the most influential series. Doc Smith taught the rest how to write space operas. The first of the Lensman series that has inspired other science fiction authors for generations. The command, control, communication, and Intelligence architectures directly inspired command centers of our aircraft carriers and Aegis cruisers of today. Don't expect a dumbed down vocabulary, or modern flowing prose, as the author was a Ph.D. chemist of great erudition, and wrote in that style. The series predicted stealth, directed energy weapons, atomic power and weapons, ABM systems, and more. Great fun.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I had read this before decades ago
reviews.reviewText: Once again I fell in love with this book. It’s even better reading it now than when I first read it. It’s well written and also puts there a concept that feels more real. Surely we are not alone in this Universe.
I'm awed by these authors of the 1930's and their ability to imagine the future. We are using some of their ideas in our time. This book is the first in a series of 6 books.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: It hasn't aged well but still a cracking read
reviews.reviewText: Ok so there's a lot of American tropes, the chaps are gallant and daring and the female characters, when they appear, tend to the beautiful but plucky bimbo end of the hero scale (the last book goes some way to correcting this but its pretty clear the 'Doc' likes women but has no idea how to write them). But it's a superbly paced, lots of (made up) science and ultimately good morality conquers all. If you can get past the elements that dated in the last near-century you still won't learn anything deep but it's so much FUN I'm surprised Hollywood haven't made a sucky version of it yet.

reviews.reviewTitle: Re read and just as engrossing
reviews.reviewText: Re read after a long time and just as engrossing. The last time I had a well read second hand paperback which I must have somewhere I hope.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 7, 2019
reviews.reviewText: To the modern younger audience for SF I suppose these books must seem a little naive, as primitive as cave paintings compared to the works of art in display at the Tate. For me they are the fundamental precursor to be valued as, forgive the pun, the foundations of contemporary additions to the genre. Likely this is possibly a jaundiced view from a nostalgic perspective but to be reunited with this franchise is a joyous occasion of a childhood reunion with dog-eared companions of yore. True they may lack a certain political correctness, hold to values of another era which jar and jostle with today, still they possess a sense of the epic, unambiguous shades of black and white, where villains are villains and damsels are rescued from their black clutches by heroes of strength and valour.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: My number one science fiction series
reviews.reviewText: In my opinion on of the best science fiction series, ever written. With a lot of fantasy in its best sense. And with a lot of deep wisdom hidden in the story. It is impossible to give a representative abstract. Must be read! I have read this series maybe 10 times! Maravilhoso! as we say in Portugal.
